trans-unit.source: A <token>sb2</token> URI is a universal resource identifier (URI) that describes the location at which an endpoint is exposed on <token>sb2</token>.
trans-unit.target: A <token>sb2</token> URI is a universal resource identifier (URI) that describes the location at which an endpoint is exposed on <token>sb2</token>.

trans-unit.source: You use a <token>sb2</token> URI when you connect with both a service and client application.
trans-unit.target: You use a <token>sb2</token> URI when you connect with both a service and client application.

trans-unit.source: You also use a <token>sb2</token> URI when you connect to retrieve SAS tokens for authentication and credential verification.
trans-unit.target: You also use a <token>sb2</token> URI when you connect to retrieve SAS tokens for authentication and credential verification.

trans-unit.source: While you can manually create the URI, or store it in the App.config file, it’s recommended that you use the <codeEntityReference qualifyHint="true">M:Microsoft.ServiceBus.ServiceBusEnvironment.CreateServiceUri(System.String,System.String,System.String)</codeEntityReference> or <codeEntityReference qualifyHint="true">M:Microsoft.ServiceBus.ServiceBusEnvironment.CreateAccessControlUri(System.String)</codeEntityReference> methods to create your URIs, as those members contain all the relevant default settings.
trans-unit.target: While you can manually create the URI, or store it in the App.config file, it’s recommended that you use the <codeEntityReference qualifyHint="true">M:Microsoft.ServiceBus.ServiceBusEnvironment.CreateServiceUri(System.String,System.String,System.String)</codeEntityReference> or <codeEntityReference qualifyHint="true">M:Microsoft.ServiceBus.ServiceBusEnvironment.CreateAccessControlUri(System.String)</codeEntityReference> methods to create your URIs, as those members contain all the relevant default settings.

trans-unit.source: <token>sb2</token> performs case-insensitive comparisons of namespaces to align with the behavior of IIS.
trans-unit.target: <token>sb2</token> performs case-insensitive comparisons of namespaces to align with the behavior of IIS.

trans-unit.source: When designing applications that support multitenancy, you should realize that <token>ac2</token> performs case-sensitive comparisons and <token>sb2</token> performs case-insensitive comparisons, if this difference in behavior produces unexpected results in your application.
trans-unit.target: When designing applications that support multitenancy, you should realize that <token>ac2</token> performs case-sensitive comparisons and <token>sb2</token> performs case-insensitive comparisons, if this difference in behavior produces unexpected results in your application.

trans-unit.source: Because <token>ac2</token> prevents creating scopes that differ only by case, this difference in behavior should not present a security issue.
trans-unit.target: Because <token>ac2</token> prevents creating scopes that differ only by case, this difference in behavior should not present a security issue.

trans-unit.source: To create a Service Bus URI
trans-unit.target: To create a Service Bus URI

trans-unit.source: Create the URI with a call to <codeEntityReference>M:Microsoft.ServiceBus.ServiceBusEnvironment.CreateServiceUri(System.String,System.String,System.String)</codeEntityReference> or <codeEntityReference>M:Microsoft.ServiceBus.ServiceBusEnvironment.CreateAccessControlUri(System.String)</codeEntityReference>, respectively.
trans-unit.target: Create the URI with a call to <codeEntityReference>M:Microsoft.ServiceBus.ServiceBusEnvironment.CreateServiceUri(System.String,System.String,System.String)</codeEntityReference> or <codeEntityReference>M:Microsoft.ServiceBus.ServiceBusEnvironment.CreateAccessControlUri(System.String)</codeEntityReference>, respectively.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to programmatically create a <token>sb2</token> URI.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to programmatically create a <token>sb2</token> URI.
